comment.author: 44274283@N07
comment._content: I love how the foliage creates a vignette.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: And well it might be a big "kerching"!  Not too often you would be in a position to identify each member of a photograph from the '30's.  Interesting looking at the siblings, the man and two outside ladies have very distinctive nose, mouths and lips shape and quite different to the other perhaps younger lady!  They are very handsome and beautifully attired.  Like [http://www.flickr.com/photos/44274283@N07] I love the impact of the flowers and foliage on the image!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/44274283@N07] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] I know! Do love the black and whites, but a photo like this makes me long for just a little colour - with what must have been a riot of May blossom and wildflowers...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 67022400@N03
comment._content:
Thank you very much for uploading the requested photo.

The woman sitting on the chair is my great great grandaunt Honora Kavanagh nee Butler (19-05-1869 - 21-12-1941), sitting next to her is her husband Martin Kavanagh (1869 - 10-06-1949). Standing from left to right are their four children: 

Mary Ellen Kavanagh (1909 - ?)
Tobias Kavanagh (1907 - 27-11-1984)
Rosey Kavanagh (1905 - ?)
Bridget Kavanagh (1906 - ?)

Martin and Honora were both school teachers and they lived in Raheenduff, The Rower, Kilkenny.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/67022400@N03] Fantastic! Thank you so much. Will add notes and tags now. Plus did you know we have a photo of Tobias taken on Saturday, 21 October 1939? A wedding photo perhaps?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30622421@N03
comment._content: What a marvellous image and great that they are all identified. I love looking at family resemblances between parents and children, and this family all look very alike.

comment.author: 67022400@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] That's very interesting! Tobias married Nora O'Leary in 1939 in St. Michael's Church, Dun Laoghaire, Dublin. Nora was born circa 1904 and died in 1988, she was from Ballingeary, Cork.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/67022400@N03] So, would imagine it's safe to say that's Nora in the photo, which by the looks of it, was taken in A.H. Poole's photographic studio in Waterford!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Here they are in the 1911 census.

comment.author: 96261063@N05
comment._content: Tobias (Toby) Kavanagh taught me Irish when I started school at the Good Counsel College, New Ross. He was at the end of his career when he taught me. I was there 72-77. There was school on Saturdays then!!! He would have been 64 or 65 in 1972 so the dates match. A nice man I remember. There's a picture of him on the school website (5th picture down) from the 50s: www.goodcounselcollege.ie/_blog/Good_Counsel_College_-_Pa...

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/96261063@N05] Thanks again - you've been a great help, especially about the handball courts/alleys. As I said to you before, lovely to hear personal reminiscences of people in our photos. And school on Saturdays? Thank the gods I missed that crime against humanity!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
